ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Being able to relate math to real-life situations.
N/a
A greater understanding of how math can be applicable to the real world environment.
I learned about algebra, precalculus, and calculus.
Basic math skills that can be applied in the real world.

I developed knowledge in several basic areas of math, such as exponents and logarithms. I got to engage with the course content in a safe environment where we were encouraged to make mistakes and learn from them. I learned a ton about how math applies to the real world and especially loved the final project where we got to focus on a specific current event or real-world phenomenon and its connection to math concepts learned through the course.
I learned algebra, exponents, solving logarithmic problems, geometric series, and probability! You also learn and engage in the connection between these mathematic topics and the real world!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: low workload, easy to do well, material covered is very basic, professor cares about student success and understanding. // Weaknesses: professor's explanations of concepts was usually confusing and hard to follow in class, even when the concepts themselves were straight forward and should be easy to understand.
Strengths would be the flexibility of peer tutors, while a weakness would be the way in which the course is taught.
Great QR for humanities students. I honestly could not have asked for a better class.
N/a
The professor is very kind and explains things thoroughly. There are also many opportunities to improve your Master Check grades and pre-class quiz grades. There are no weaknesses.
Minimal weaknesses but strengths are that it makes it attainable to pass.

The strengths of the course are that the topics are interesting and relevant to real life, the content is digestible by non-STEM majors seeking a QR credit, the professor is incredible, and you get to retake the pre-class quizzes and mastery checks to increase your grades. Some weaknesses are that certain units are particularly harder than others and problem sets cannot be redone.

Strengths- Meghan is a huge strength! Also, the way the class is structured is very conducive to learning, and I enjoyed it very much.
Weaknesses- everything we covered was either in class or on the weekly quizzes so the book was a waste of money. I wish the problem sets were posted on a PDF because that was all the book was used for.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would only recommend this course to students who have not learned about foundational math concepts (rules of exponents, logarithms, interest formula, basic probability) previously. I took this class because I am a humanities major and was looking for a lowkey math class. While this class was lowkey, everything we covered I had already learned about in my middle and high school math classes. I think it is possible for easy/gut classes to still be educational, but I don't feel like I learned anything new in this class. This contributed to me not feeling excited about learning.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student if they are looking for a QR credit to fill.
Yes!  Professor Anderson is a wonderful teacher and her class was a joy to be a part of. The class is formulated to make maths understandable and enjoyable for all. I highly recommend this class!
Yes if you are in need of a QR as a humanities student.
only if they needed a QR credit and were not strong in maths. I appreciated the course as someone who found maths hard but I think the course could be taught better.
N/a

If you need a QR credit, yes. Honestly, you won't learn much from this class, but it's mostly easy. I will warn you, Professor Anderson (who is great) tells everyone that the final "isn't required" when it absolutely is. Even if you get a perfect score otherwise, you need like an 85 on the final to get an A. Luckily, the final was only 6 questions and mostly easy. Good class, just beware!

Yes 100% I would recommend this course especially if you are someone who isn't very good at math. The professor makes sure that everyone is able to learn the concepts and do well in the class no matter their math background. Low workload and low stress class.
Yes. Especially if they have no background in mathematics.

I highly recommend this course to other students. It was a lot of fun, and the workload was manageable. The content is super interesting, and I learned many new concepts not covered in my high school math classes.

Absolutely!
This course is so fun and you will learn a lot (unless you already took calculus in college!)
It's a great QR credit for ANYONE interested in math (I promise it's not that bad! You get to apply it to real-world problems which makes it WAY more interesting and engaging)
I highly recommend you take this class! And take it with Meghan!

extras.title: MATH 107 01 - Mathematics in the Real World
